title: Norris Green Park
text:
Norris Green Park in <a href="Norris%20Green">Norris Green</a>, <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, England is a <a href="city%20park">city park</a> situated between Broad Lane and Lorenzo Drive.
The park contains the ruin of Norris Green, the original name of the grand mansion built by the Norris family in the fields and pastureland near <a href="West%20Derby">West Derby</a>. The park was created from the gardens and grounds of the mansion. Norris Green gave its name to the vast, <a href="council%20house">council</a> estate built to ease the housing crisis of the 1920s on land given to the city by Lord Derby of <a href="Knowsley%20Hall">Knowsley Hall</a>. He donated the land on the provision that no public houses were to be built within the estate.
The park was transferred to council ownership in 1933 to be used as a public space.
Over time, the gardens became overgrown but more recently a group of volunteers, Friends of Norris Green Park (FoNGP), has been working to create new opportunities to improve the park for the benefit of local people and residents of the city.
Norris Green mansion.
The ruins of Norris Green are all that remains of the mansion built in 1830 to replace the original mansion built in the 17th century by the Norris family. The building itself was demolished in 1931 leaving just one wall of <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> blocks as the only remaining example of the <a href="classical%20architecture">classical architecture</a>. Above the arch is a crest with the Latin inscription ALTE VOLO ("I fly high").
The standing remains, described as a stable block, are of Grade II <a href="listed%20building">listed building</a> status.
